title: Boris urged to take action on sugar – and told nanny state rhetoric doesn't cut the mustard
text:
Boris Johnson has been accused of "sheltering behind flowery rhetoric about nanny statism" as NHS leaders call for firm action on sugar.

Health chiefs urged the Prime Minister to take “personal leadership” on the matter ahead of a report by the Chief Medical Officer which is expected to call for an extension of the sugar tax.

Chris Hopson, chief executive of NHS Providers, which represents health trusts, likened such action to the ban on smoking in public places, in improving the nation’s health, and lifting pressures on hospitals.

Shortly before becoming Prime Minister, Mr Johnson has made clear his opposition to “sin taxes” and spoken out his concerns about “the continuing creep of the nanny state”.

Dame Sally Davies, who has just stood down as England’s chief medical officer, had already been commissioned by the Health Secretary to carry out a review of obesity.

Her report, due to be published on Thursday, is expected to call for the tax on sugary drinks to be extended further.
description: Boris Johnson has been accused of "sheltering behind flowery rhetoric about nanny statism" as NHS leaders call for firm action on sugar.
